revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person |name = Luke Harding |image = Luke Harding.jpeg |birth_date = |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |education = [[University College, Oxford]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])}} |occupation = Journalist }} '''Luke Daniel Harding''' is a British journalist who is a [[foreign correspondent (journalism)|foreign correspondent]] for ''[[The Guardian]]''. He was based in [[Russia]] for ''The Guardian'' from 2007 until, returning from a stay in the UK on 5 February 2011, he was refused re-entry to Russia and deported back the same day.<ref>Luke Harding (23 September 2011). [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/sep/23/luke-harding-russia "Enemy of the state"], ''[[The Guardian]]''.</ref> ''The Guardian'' said his expulsion was linked with his critical articles on Russia,<ref name=Guardian>Dan Sabbagh (9 February 2011). [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/feb/09/russia-deportation-guardian-journalist "Russia U-turns over Guardian journalist's deportation"], ''[[The Guardian]]'.'</ref> a claim denied by the Russian government. After the reversal of the decision on 9 February and the granting of a short-term [[Visa (document)|visa]], Harding chose not to seek a further visa extension.<ref name=Guardian/> His 2011 book ''[[Mafia State (book)|Mafia State]]'' discusses his experience in Russia and the political system under [[Vladimir Putin]], which he describes as a [[mafia state]].
==Early life and career== Harding graduated with an [[International Baccalaureate]] diploma from UWC [[Atlantic College]], South Wales and studied English at [[University College, Oxford]]. While there he edited the student newspaper ''[[Cherwell (newspaper)|Cherwell]]''. He worked for ''[[The Sunday Correspondent]]'', the ''[[The Argus (Brighton)|Evening Argus]]'' in Brighton and then the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' before joining ''The Guardian'' in 1996.<ref name=reutersinstitute-bio>{{cite web |url=https://reutersinstitute.politics.ox.ac.uk/people/luke-harding |title=Luke Harding |publisher=Reuters Institute for the Study of Journalism |accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref>
He has lived in and reported from [[Delhi]], [[Berlin]], and [[Moscow]], and has covered wars in [[Afghanistan]], [[Iraq]], and [[Libya]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/profile/lukeharding Luke Harding's contributor page], theguardian.com</ref> In 2014 he was the recipient of the James Cameron prize for his work on Russia, [[Ukraine]], [[WikiLeaks]], and [[Edward Snowden]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/nov/26/guardian-luke-harding-james-cameron-prize-wikileaks-ukraine-snowden "Guardian’s Luke Harding wins prestigious James Cameron prize"], "[[The Guardian]]"</ref>
==Russian expulsion== In February 2011, Harding was refused re-entry into Russia. According to Harding, this made him the first foreign journalist to be expelled from Russia since the end of the [[Cold War]]. ''The Guardian'' said his expulsion was linked with his unflattering coverage of Russia, including speculation about [[Vladimir Putin]]'s wealth and Putin's knowledge of the London assassination of ex-Russian spy [[Alexander Litvinenko]].<ref name=Guardian/> The director of [[Index on Censorship]], [[John Kampfner]], said "The Russian government's treatment of Luke Harding is petty and vindictive, and evidence – if more was needed – of the poor state of free expression in that country."<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/feb/07/guardian-moscow-correspondent-expelled-from-russia ''Guardian's Moscow correspondent expelled from Russia''], ''[[The Guardian]]''</ref> Elsa Vidal, head of the European and Central Asia desk at the media freedom watchdog, was quoted in ''[[The Washington Post]]'' as saying: "This is a serious and shocking step, unprecedented since the Cold War [...] It's an attempt to force correspondents working for foreign media in Moscow to engage in self-censorship."<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/08/AR2011020803769.html ''Russia expels U.K. reporter Luke Harding, who covered corruption''], ''[[The Washington Post]]''</ref>
However, on the following day, Russian Foreign Minister [[Sergei Lavrov]] explained at a press conference that no visa cancellation had taken place and the problem had been caused by the fact that Harding's visa had expired, a statement disputed by Harding due to his visa being valid until May of that year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/lukeharding1968/status/737282233447415808|title=Luke Harding on Twitter|publisher=}}</ref> According to Lavrov, Harding had requested an exceptional visa extension until May which was approved. Lavrov also added that Harding had previously broken the rules of his press accreditation by visiting the area of [[counter-terrorism]] operations without informing the relevant security authorities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ria.ru/media/20110208/331950001.html|title=Лавров: Люк Хардинг неоднократно нарушал правила аккредитации в России|date=8 February 2011|publisher=}}</ref>
The expulsion preceded a visit to Britain by Lavrov, which led to suggestions from [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] MP [[Chris Bryant]] that the British government might rescind Lavrov's invitation.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/feb/08/russia-visit-guardian-journalist-expelled ''Call to halt Russian foreign minister's visit after Guardian journalist expelled''], The Guardian</ref> On 9 February, Russia reversed the decision not to re-admit him<ref name=Guardian/> although it only granted him a short term visa. Harding chose not to seek a further visa and returned to the UK in February. Harding has said that during his time in Russia he was the subject of largely psychological harassment by the [[Federal Security Service (Russia)|Federal Security Service]], whom he alleges were unhappy at the stories he wrote.<ref>{{cite news |title=Enemy of the state |author=Luke Harding |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/sep/23/luke-harding-russia |newspaper=The Guardian |date=23 September 2011 |accessdate=25 September 2011 |location=London}}</ref>
==WikiLeaks== In 2011, a book written by Harding and [[David Leigh (journalist)|David Leigh]] was published by Vintage Books in the US and Guardian Faber in the UK.<ref>[http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/books/review-wikileaks-inside-julian-assanges-war-on-secrecy-by-david-leigh-and-luke-harding-26715172.html "Review: Wikileaks: Inside Julian Assange's War On Secrecy by David Leigh and Luke Harding"], ''The Independent'' (Eire), 18 November 2011</ref> ''[[WikiLeaks: Inside Julian Assange's War on Secrecy]]'' was made into a Hollywood film, ''[[The Fifth Estate (film)|The Fifth Estate]]'' (2013). WikiLeaks condemned the film, stating that its depiction of Assange rushing to publication with no redactions was false.
On November 27, 2018, Harding co-authored a piece for ''The Guardian'' claiming that Julian Assange and [[Paul Manafort]] had become familiar in the course of meetings at the Ecuadorian embassy. Commentators including [[Preet Bharara]] and [[Benjamin Wittes]] stated that they would be interested in seeing more evidence as the sources in Harding's piece were described only as "sources". Manafort and Assange both denied ever having met with the latter threatening legal action against ''The Guardian''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2018/11/the-guardian-paul-manafort-julian-assange|title="It might be the biggest get this year": How the Guardian's bombshell set off its own little media world war|first=Joe|last=Pompeo|publisher=Vanity Fair|date=2018-11-27|accessdate=2018-11-29}}</ref>
==Edward Snowden== {{main|The Snowden Files}} Harding's book on [[Edward Snowden]], ''[[The Snowden Files]]'' (2014), received a glowing review from ''[[The New York Times]]''{{'}}s [[Michiko Kakutani]],<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/05/books/the-snowden-files-by-luke-harding.html?_r=1 "The Needles in the Monumental N.S.A. Haystack ‘The Snowden Files,’ by Luke Harding"] ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref> who noted that it “reads like a le Carré novel crossed with something by Kafka. . A fast-paced, almost novelistic narrative. . .. [The book] gives readers . . a succinct overview of the momentous events of the past year. . . . Leave[s] readers with an acute understanding of the serious issues involved”. Additionally, it received positive reviews from several other major publications, including ''[[The Guardian]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2014/feb/13/snowden-files-luke-harding-review|title=The Snowden Files by Luke Harding – review|first=David|last=Runciman|date=13 February 2014|website=the Guardian}}</ref> the ''[[London Review of Books]]'',<ref>[http://www.lrb.co.uk/v36/n04/daniel-soar/incendiary-devices Daniel Soar reviews ‘The Snowden Files’ by Luke Harding · LRB 20 February 2014] – '[[The London Review of Books]]'</ref> and the ''[[Washington Post]]'',<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/the-snowden-files-the-inside-story-of-the-worlds-most-wanted-man-by-luke-harding/2014/02/14/60df3c66-934f-11e3-84e1-27626c5ef5fb_story.html "Opinions ‘The Snowden Files: The Inside Story of the World’s Most Wanted Man’ by Luke Harding"] ''[[The Washington Post]]''</ref> as well as a mixed review from ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'s'' [[David Blair (journalist)|David Blair]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/bookreviews/10628503/The-Snowden-Files-by-Luke-Harding-review.html|title=The Snowden Files by Luke Harding, review|first=David|last=Blair|date=11 February 2014|publisher=|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}}</ref> It was adapted into a film, ''[[Snowden (film)|Snowden]]'', directed by [[Oliver Stone]] and starring [[Joseph Gordon-Levitt]], released in September 2016.
==Alexander Litvinenko== In 2016, Harding published ''A Very Expensive Poison'', an account of the [[Poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko|murder of the Russian ex-KGB whistle-blower]] and outspoken Putin critic [[Alexander Litvinenko]]. The book garnered a positive response from reviewers, including from the ''[[The Spectator|Spectator]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spectator.co.uk/2016/03/the-litvinenko-case-mayfair-murder-most-foul/|title=The Litvinenko case: Mayfair murder most foul - The Spectator|date=26 March 2016|publisher=}}</ref> ''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/mar/29/a-very-expensive-poison-by-luke-harding-review-definitive|title=A Very Expensive Poison review – definitive account of Litvinenko murder |publisher=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref> ''[[The Times|Times]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/a-very-expensive-poison-by-luke-harding-w9jg6rh82|title=A Very Expensive Poison by Luke Harding|first=Michael|last=Burleigh|date=19 March 2016|publisher=|via=www.thetimes.co.uk}}</ref> and ''[[London Review of Books]]'';<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lrb.co.uk/v38/n07/peter-pomerantsev/murder-in-mayfair|title=Murder in Mayfair|first=Peter|last=Pomerantsev|date=31 March 2016|publisher=|pages=3–6|via=London Review of Books}}</ref> Robert Fox, writing for the ''[[Evening Standard]]'' called it 'one of the best political thrillers [he had] come across in years'.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/books/a-very-expensive-poison-the-definitive-story-of-the-murder-of-litvinenko-and-russia-s-war-with-the-a3200626.html|title=A Very Expensive Poison by Luke Harding - review|publisher=}}</ref>'' [[Lucy Prebble]] has adapted the book for the stage, with the play due to première in [[The Old Vic]] theatre, London in 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/apr/29/alexander-litvinenko-murder-adapted-for-stage-lucy-prebble-luke-harding|title=Spies, assassins and strip clubs: death of Alexander Litvinenko adapted for stage}}</ref>
==Donald Trump and Russia== In November 2017, Harding published ''Collusion: Secret Meetings, Dirty Money, and How Russia Helped Donald Trump Win'' on the subject of [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]]. The book examines the [[Donald Trump–Russia dossier|dossier]] by a former British spy [[Christopher Steele]], among other things.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2017/nov/15/how-trump-walked-into-putins-web-luke |title=How Trump walked into Putin’s web |work=[[The Guardian]] |author=Luke Harding |date=15 November 2017 |accessdate=15 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Collusion: Secret Meetings, Dirty Money, and How Russia Helped Donald Trump Win |publisher=Vintage |author=Luke Harding |year=2017 |isbn=978-0525562511}}</ref>
In a November 2018 ''Guardian'' article with Dan Collyns, Harding cited sources which stated that [[Paul Manafort]] made personal visits to [[Julian Assange]] in 2013, 2015, and 2016.<ref>{{cite news |last1= Harding |first1= Luke |last2= Collyns|first2= Dan |date= 27 November 2018 |title= Manafort held secret talks with Assange in Ecuadorian embassy |url= https://web.archive.org/web/20181127143814/https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/nov/27/manafort-held-secret-talks-with-assange-in-ecuadorian-embassy |location= |newspaper = The Guardian}}</ref> The extraordinary claims were met with denials, and the article has been characterised as possibly journalism's biggest scoop of the year, or its biggest blunder.<ref>{{cite news |last= Pompeo |first= Joe |date= 27 November 2018|title= "It Might Be the Biggest Get This Year": How The Guardian’s Bombshell Set Off Its Own Little Media World War |url= https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2018/11/the-guardian-paul-manafort-julian-assange |newspaper= Vanity Fair }}</ref>
==Works== * ''The Liar: Fall of Jonathan Aitken'', [[Penguin Books]] (1997), co-written with [[David Leigh (journalist)|David Leigh]] and [[David Pallister]]. An account of how the British politician [[Jonathan Aitken]] sued the Guardian newspaper over sleaze allegations and was jailed for [[perjury]]. * ''WikiLeaks: Inside Julian Assange's War on Secrecy'', [[Guardian Books]] (1 February 2011), {{ISBN|978-0-85265-239-8}}, co-written with [[David Leigh (journalist)|David Leigh]]. A biography of [[Julian Assange]], the founder of [[WikiLeaks]]. ''WikiLeaks: Inside Julian Assange's War on Secrecy'' and [[Daniel Domscheit-Berg]]'s ''WikiLeaks: My Time with Julian Assange and the World’s Most Dangerous Website'' was adapted into a screenplay by [[Josh Singer]], and became the film, ''[[The Fifth Estate (film)|The Fifth Estate]]''. Co-produced by [[DreamWorks]] and [[Participant Media]], it was directed by [[Bill Condon]] and starred [[Benedict Cumberbatch]] and [[Daniel Brühl]]. It was released on 11 October 2013 in the UK and 18 October 2013 in the US.<ref>Deadline, The. (20 May 2013) [http://www.deadline.com/2013/05/dreamworks-the-fifth-estate-release-date-shifts-month-delivery-man-postponed/ DreamWorks' 'Fifth Estate' Release Date Shifts Month; 'Delivery Man' Moved To Nov.] ''[[Deadline Hollywood]]''. Retrieved on 12 August 2013.</ref> * ''[[Mafia State (book)|Mafia State: How One Reporter Became An Enemy Of The Brutal New Russia]]''{{ref|A|a}}, [[Random House]] (NY, 22 September 2011), {{ISBN|978-0-85265-247-3}}; [[Guardian Books]] (UK, 29 September 2011), {{ISBN|978-0-85265-247-3}}. An account of his experience in Russia and interactions with the FSB. The title "[[mafia state]]" comes from one of the American diplomatic cables obtained by WikiLeaks.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2011/oct/21/mafia-state-luke-harding-review Mafia State by Luke Harding – review], ''[[The Guardian]]''</ref> * ''Libya: Murder in Benghazi and the Fall of Gaddafi'' (20 October 2012), co-written with Martin Chulov. Short e-book, account of the moment of [[Gaddafi's capture]] and the current state of Libya.<ref>[http://www.guardianshorts.co.uk/browse-ebooks/news-and-politics-ebooks/libya-murder-in-benghazi-and-the-fall-of-gaddafi-ebook guardian''shorts'', Libya: Murder in Benghazi and the Fall of Gaddafi] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130715035326/http://www.guardianshorts.co.uk/browse-ebooks/news-and-politics-ebooks/libya-murder-in-benghazi-and-the-fall-of-gaddafi-ebook |date=15 July 2013 }}</ref> * ''The Snowden Files: The Inside Story of the World's Most Wanted Man'', [[Vintage Books]] (NY, 7 February 2014), {{ISBN|978-0804173520}}; Guardian Faber Publishing (UK, 6 February 2014), {{ISBN|978-1783350353}}. Harding tells Edward Snowden's story from the day he left his girlfriend in Honolulu carrying a hard drive full of secrets, to the weeks of his secret-spilling in Hong Kong, to his battle for asylum and his exile in Moscow. * ''A Very Expensive Poison: the Definitive Story of the Murder of Litvinenko'' is published in March 2016 by Guardian Faber in the UK. {{ISBN|978-1783350933}}. * {{cite book |title=Collusion: Secret Meetings, Dirty Money, and How Russia Helped Donald Trump Win |publisher=Vintage |year=2017 |isbn=978-0525562511}} (An excerpt titled [https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2017/11/19/trump-first-moscow-trip-215842 "The Hidden History of Trump’s First Trip to Moscow."] was published by ''[[Politico]]'' on November 19, 2017.)
==Notes== :{{note|A|a}}Published in the US as ''Expelled''
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *{{Twitter}} * {{IMDb name|4816469}} *[https://www.theguardian.com/profile/lukeharding Column archives] at ''[[The Guardian]]'' *[http://journalisted.com/luke-harding Article archive] at [[Journalisted]] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20111122132657/http://uwc.org/uwc_life/alumni_profiles/media/luke_harding.aspx Profile] at [[United World Colleges]]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Harding, Luke}} [[Category:Alumni of University College, Oxford]] [[Category:British male journalists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:The Guardian journalists]] [[Category:People educated at Atlantic College]] [[Category:Censorship in Russia]] [[Category:Anti-Russian sentiment]] [[Category:People associated with Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]]

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=January 2010}} {{Like resume|date=January 2010}} }}
'''Matt James''' is a British garden designer, horticulturist and university lecturer who rose to fame on the TV programme '[[The City Gardener]]' which is shown on the [[UK]]'s Channel 4. Originally from [[Essex]], he now resides with his wife in [[Cornwall]].
Matt's gardening career began when he was a teenager working on a small farm. He then went on to study at various horticultural colleges and work at [[nursery (horticulture)|nurseries]]. He was honoured in 2000 as Londoner-of-the-Year in the field of environment and regeneration, in recognition of his work establishing a successful circuit of [[farmers' market]]s in the capital. Today his enthusiasm has led him to teaching, and he now lectures on a part-time basis in garden design at [[Falmouth University]] in Cornwall.
Matt has also won two gold awards at the annual California Landscape Contractors' Association Awards.
Matt's greatest passion as a gardener is trees - he is a genuine, 21st century tree hugger and has made it his mission in life to get as many cityfolk as possible planting trees again.
The success of the City Gardener TV programme has also led onto other successful TV programmes - ''Matt James Eco Eden'' is shown on [[UKTV]] and he is also the co-host of ''Selling Houses''.
Matt James has also filmed an American version of the City Gardener called Urban Outsiders for [[HGTV]], featuring gardens in [[New York City|New York]] and [[Los Angeles]]. The first 13 shows aired in 2006, the remaining 13 shows are due to air shortly.{{When|date=January 2010}}
Matt has also released a book - The City Garden Bible, released in 2005, The City Gardener in 2003 and The City Gardener:Urban Oasis in 2004.
Matt has also released a range of plants, exotic trees and shrubs named the 'Matt James Collection' which are sold through various outlets in the UK.
Matt James presented an episode of ''[[Great British Garden Revival]]'' that aired on BBC Two in 2014.
==External links== * [http://www.channel4.com/4homes/on-tv/more-programmes/about-matt-james-08-06-19_p_1.html The City Gardener]
{{DEFAULTSORT:James, Matt}} [[Category:English horticulturists]] [[Category:English television presenters]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Cornish people]] [[Category:People from Essex]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox historical event |Event_Name = Michael Jackson memorial service |Image_Name = MichaelJacksonMemorial 02.jpg |Image_Caption = Held at the [[Staples Center]], where [[Michael Jackson]] rehearsed on June 24, 2009 (one day before his death). |AKA = |Participants = Rev. Lucious Smith, [[Smokey Robinson]], [[Mariah Carey]], [[Trey Lorenz]], [[Queen Latifah]], [[Lionel Richie]], [[John Mayer]], [[Stevie Wonder]], [[Kobe Bryant]], [[Magic Johnson]], [[Jennifer Hudson]], [[Berry Gordy]], [[Rev. Jesse Jackson]], [[Rev. Al Sharpton]], [[John Mayer]], [[Brooke Shields]], [[Jermaine Jackson]], [[Martin Luther King III]], [[Bernice King]], [[Sheila Jackson-Lee]], [[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]], [[Shaheen Jafargholi]], [[Kenny Ortega]], [[Judith Hill]], [[Marlon Jackson]], [[Janet Jackson]], [[Paris Jackson (actress)|Paris Jackson]], [[Orianthi Panagaris]] |Location = [[Staples Center]], [[Los Angeles, California]], United States |Date = July 7, 2009 |Result = |URL = }}
A public memorial service for [[Michael Jackson]]<!--NOTE: Per WP:BOLDTITLE, the title should not be bolded in this case.--> was held on 7 July 2009 at the [[Staples Center]] in [[Los Angeles]], California, twelve days after [[Death of Michael Jackson|his death]]. The event was preceded by a private family service at [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Hollywood Hills)#Court of Liberty|Forest Lawn Memorial Park's Hall of Liberty]] in [[Hollywood Hills]], and followed by a gathering in [[Beverly Hills]] for Jackson's family and close friends.
Jackson's closed, solid-bronze casket, plated with 14-karat gold and lined with blue velvet, which was not originally expected to be at the memorial service, arrived just before 10:00 a.m. local time, when it was placed in front of the stage. The memorial began a few minutes after 10:30 a.m. with music and a [[eulogy]] from [[Pastor]] Lucious Smith. The stage was filled with floral arrangements, with photographs and film of Jackson and [[the Jackson 5]] projected onto screens at the back. Music and video montages traced his life from the beginning of his career to the end.<ref>{{cite news | author=TVGuideNews| title=Top Moments: Michael Jackson Memorial | url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Jackson-Memorial-Moments-1007748.aspx | work=TVGuide.com | date=July 7, 2009 | accessdate=July 8, 2009}}</ref>
Jackson's brothers, sitting in the front row, each wore a single white [[sequin]]ed glove in tribute to their brother. [[Mariah Carey]], [[Stevie Wonder]], [[Lionel Richie]], [[Jennifer Hudson]], [[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]], [[Jermaine Jackson]], and [[Shaheen Jafargholi]] sang Jackson's songs, and [[John Mayer]] played guitar. [[Berry Gordy]], [[Brooke Shields]], and [[Smokey Robinson]] gave eulogies, while [[Queen Latifah]] read "We Had Him", a poem written for the occasion by [[Maya Angelou]].<!--please don't wikilink all the city names--> The Reverend [[Al Sharpton]] received a standing ovation when he told Jackson's children, "Wasn't nothing strange about your daddy. It was strange what your daddy had to deal with."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www2.macleans.ca/2009/07/07/there-was-nothing-strange-about-your-daddy|title=Video of Sharpton's eulogy|work=Macleans|date=July 7, 2009|publisher=macleans.ca}}</ref>
Toward the end, the family gathered on stage to offer the final eulogies. Jackson's then-11-year-old daughter, Paris, while unable to give her speech without crying, told the crowd, "I just want to say, ever since I was born, Daddy has been the best father you could ever imagine, and I just want to say I love him... so much."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/blog/2009/jul/07/michaeljackson|title= Liveblogging Michael Jackson's funeral and memorial service|work=The Guardian|date=July 7, 2009 | location=London | first=Oliver | last=Burkeman | accessdate=May 12, 2010}}</ref> Additionally, an emotional [[Marlon Jackson]] said, "Maybe now, Michael, they will leave you alone."<ref name=BBCJuly7>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/8137700.stm|title=Emotional farewell to King of Pop|work=BBC News|publisher=bbcnews.com|date=July 7, 2009|accessdate=September 3, 2009}}</ref>
==Background== The memorial service was organized by Jackson's concert promoter, [[AEG Live]], and AEG Ehrlich Ventures, LLC ([[Kenneth Ehrlich]] - Executive Producer),<ref>{{cite web|first=Tim|last=Parks|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/showbiz/a163368/aeg-to-release-jackson-memorial-tickets.html|title=AEG to release Jackson memorial tickets|work=Digital Spy|date=July 3, 2009}}</ref> who gave away 17,500 free tickets to fans worldwide through an online lottery that attracted over 1.2 million applicants in 24 hours,<ref>{{cite news|last=Allen|first=Nick|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/michael-jackson/5744787/Thirteen-applications-per-second-for-Michael-Jackson-memorial-tickets.html|title=Thirteen applications per second for Michael|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=July 6, 2009|publisher=telegraph.co.uk | location=London}}</ref> and over a half-billion hits to the webpage.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2009/07/michael-jackson-5.html |title=Website for Jackson tickets gets 500 million hits in first hour | L.A. Now | Los Angeles Times |publisher=Latimesblogs.latimes.com |date=July 3, 2009 |accessdate=July 28, 2009}}</ref> An estimated 750,000<ref>{{cite web|first=Leanne|last=Suter | date=July 2, 2009 |url=http://abclocal.go.com/kabc/story?section=news/entertainment&id=6895575&rss=rss-kabc-article-6895575 |title=Jackson memorial set for Staples Center|publisher=ABClocal.com |accessdate=August 7, 2009}}</ref> up to a million fans were expected to congregate outside Staples Center<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.azcentral.com/ent/celeb/articles/2009/07/03/20090703michael-jacksons-starstudded-memorial.html |title=One million fans expected at Michael Jackson memorial|publisher=azcentral.com |date=July 3, 2009 |accessdate=July 28, 2009}}</ref><ref name=Starmagazine7>.{{cite web|url=http://www.starmagazine.com/michael_jackson_memorial/news/15798|work=Star Magazine|date=July 3, 2009|title=1 Million Expected at Jackson's Star-Studded Memorial}}</ref> but due to Los Angeles's $530 million budget crisis, city and police officials urged fans to stay home.<ref name=Memorial1>{{cite news|work=CNN|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/US/07/07/michael.jackson.security/index.html?eref=rss_showbiz|publisher=CNN.com|date=July 7, 2009|title=Cost only security problem at Jackson memorial | accessdate=May 12, 2010}}</ref> Street and highway exit around the Staples Center were sealed off,<ref name=Memorial1/> and 3,000 officers, the largest security effort planned since the [[1984 Summer Olympics|1984 Olympics]],<ref name=Memorial1/> were on duty at a cost of $1.4 million to the city.<ref name=Memorial2>{{cite news|last=Vercammen|first=Paul|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/Music/07/08/michael.jackson.cost/index.html?eref=rss_topstories|work=CNN|publisher=CNN.com|date=July 8, 2009|accessdate=September 3, 2009|title=Mayor's office: Michael Jackson memorial cost L.A. $1.4 million}}</ref> The motorcade for Jackson's casket was headed by two police motorcycle outriders, and the LA freeways were closed for the journey of approximately {{convert|11|mi|km}} from Forest Lawn to the Staples Center.<ref name=SinghJuly7>{{cite news|last=Singh|first=Anita|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/michael-jackson/5768272/Michael-Jackson-funeral-to-take-place-in-Los-Angeles.html|title=Michael Jackson funeral to take place in Los Angeles|work=The Daily Telegraph|publisher=telegraph.co.uk|date=July 7, 2009 | location=London}}</ref> The service was broadcast live around the world. The United States viewership was extremely high taking into consideration that the service was unusually held on a workday (Tuesday) and a host of people reported watching the service during work.
==Service== The service began with [[Smokey Robinson]] reading messages of condolences from [[Diana Ross]] and former [[President of South Africa|South African President]] [[Nelson Mandela]]. A gospel choir sang [[Andrae Crouch]]'s "Soon and Very Soon" as Jackson's casket entered (culminating around the line "you will see the King"), followed by statements from Pastor Lucious Smith. [[Mariah Carey]] and [[Trey Lorenz]] then sang "[[I'll Be There (The Jackson 5 song)|I'll Be There]]", a number one single for both [[The Jackson 5]] and Carey and Lorenz. This was followed by a statement from [[Queen Latifah]], who also read "We Had Him", a poem written by [[Maya Angelou]] for the occasion. [[Lionel Richie]], Jackson's friend and his co-writer on "[[We Are the World]]", performed the song "[[Heroes (Commodores album)|Jesus Is Love]]" by [[The Commodores]]. In the eulogy of [[Berry Gordy]], founder of [[Motown Records]], he stated, "In fact, the more I think and talk about Michael Jackson, I feel the King of Pop is not big enough for him. I think he is simply the greatest entertainer that ever lived." The statement was met with the longest standing ovation of the night.<ref>{{cite web |title=Farewell to a King|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20292614,00.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090810203619/http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20292614,00.html|dead-url=no|archive-date=August 10, 2009|work=People |date=July 20, 2009 |accessdate=November 26, 2009}} </ref><ref>{{cite web |title=BERRY GORDY - GORDY BRINGS MOURNERS TO THEIR FEET WITH JACKSON TRIBUTE|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/news.nsf/story/gordy-brings-mourners-to-their-feet-with-jackson-tribute_1108973|work=Contact Music |date=July 7, 2009 |accessdate=November 26, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Michael Jackson hailed as greatest entertainer, best dad|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKTRE5615KN20090708|work=Reuters UK |date=July 8, 2009 |accessdate=November 26, 2009}}</ref>
[[Image:MichaelJacksonMemorial 05.jpg|thumb|left|250px|A crowd of spectators gathering outside the Staples Center during the memorial service.]]
A video montage of Michael Jackson's life followed. [[Stevie Wonder]] spoke, played a small portion of "I Can't Help It", a song from ''[[Off the Wall (album)|Off the Wall]]'' that Wonder co-wrote, then performed a version of his songs "[[Never Dreamed You'd Leave in Summer]]" and "[[They Won't Go When I Go]]". Next [[Kobe Bryant]] spoke about Jackson's humanitarian work, and [[Magic Johnson]] (who had appeared in the music video for "[[Remember the Time]]") recalled his memories of Jackson. Accompanied by a dancing chorus, [[Jennifer Hudson]] performed "[[Will You Be There]]" a song Jackson wrote and performed for the 1993 film ''[[Free Willy]]'' which is also from his ''[[Dangerous (Michael Jackson album)|Dangerous]]'' album, along with the dancers who would have been on stage with Jackson for his O2 concerts. [[John Mayer]] played guitar on a mainly instrumental version of "[[Human Nature (Michael Jackson song)|Human Nature]]" from Jackson's ''[[Thriller (Michael Jackson album)|Thriller]]''. [[Brooke Shields]] then spoke about the personal time she spent with Jackson, read excerpts from ''[[The Little Prince]]'', and said that his favorite song was [[Charlie Chaplin]]'s "[[Smile (Charlie Chaplin song)|Smile]]", which was then performed by [[Jermaine Jackson]].
[[Martin Luther King, Jr.]]'s children, [[Martin Luther King III|Martin III]] and [[Bernice King|Bernice]], then stated that Michael Jackson was the best that he could be. [[Sheila Jackson-Lee]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|D]]-[[Texas's 18th congressional district|Texas]], Houston), representing the [[United States House of Representatives]], emphasized that in the US, people are "[[innocent until proven guilty]]" (as the crowd cheered) then spoke about his "American story" plus his meetings with foreign diplomats, and that "Michael never stopped giving". She then went on to claim him as an American legend and world humanitarian (House Resolution 600<ref>http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?c111:H.RES.600:</ref>), closing her speech with a military salute as she said, "Michael Jackson, I salute you." [[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]] walked to the casket and then sang Larry Grossman and Buzz Kohan's "[[Gone Too Soon]]", which Jackson recorded as a tribute for [[Ryan White]] after his death; Usher cried near the end of the song as he placed his hand on the casket, but managed to finish. Following Usher, a clip from ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]'' in 1969 featuring the Jackson 5's rendition of [[The Miracles]]' "[[Who's Lovin' You]]" was shown. Following this, the song's composer and Miracles lead singer, [[Smokey Robinson]], spoke about and made joking remarks about the Jackson 5 covering his song, and continued with a speech. [[Shaheen Jafargholi]] from ''[[Britain's Got Talent]]'' then performed the song.
Jackson choreographer [[Kenny Ortega]] presented Jafargholi, honored Jackson, and introduced the final performance of the memorial, which Jackson had been slated to perform during the ''[[This Is It (Michael Jackson concerts)|This Is It]]'' dates. The concerts' chorus singers, Darrell Phinnessee, Ken Stacey, [[Dorian Holley]], [[Judith Hill]] and guitarist [[Orianthi]] performed "[[We Are the World]]" and were joined on the stage by several of the guest speakers and performers as well as the Jackson family for the final chorus. With the entire group still on stage, Hill then led a performance of "[[Heal the World]]", with the remainder of the group joining in the chorus. Jackson's family then addressed the crowd. Jermaine—who had earlier performed a tearful rendition of "Smile"—gave a brief speech, followed by a eulogy by [[Marlon Jackson|Marlon]], where he tributed his stillborn twin brother Brandon, who died at birth, telling his younger brother to "give him a hug" for himself as a favor. Marlon then handed the microphone over to [[Janet Jackson|Janet]], but in a move that came as a surprise to the show's organizers, she said that her niece, Paris, had something to say. Surrounded by her paternal aunts and uncles, Paris emotionally addressed the crowd before collapsing in tears and being escorted off the stage by her family:
{{cquote|I just want to say. Ever since I was born, Daddy has been the best father you could ever imagine...and I just want to say I love him... so much.}}
[[Image:MichaelJacksonMemorial 01.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Outside the Staples Center during the memorial service.]]
Marlon Jackson then thanked the crowd in attendance, and the family escorted the casket out of the arena while an instrumental version of "[[Man in the Mirror]]" was performed. A microphone placed center stage was lit by spotlight while the instrumental version of "Man in the Mirror" played out, symbolizing the 'absence' of Michael Jackson. Many in the crowd applauded and cheered as Michael Jackson's coffin was carried out of the building. Pastor Lucious Smith closed the service with a prayer and quote saying "I'm alive and I'm here forever" from the [[Paul McCartney]]/[[Michael Jackson]] duet song ''[[Pipes of Peace|The Man]]''. The memorial was finished at 12:48 p.m.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8139422.stm |title=Entertainment | Reporters' log: Jackson memorial |publisher=BBC News |date= July 7, 2009|accessdate=July 8, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Itzkoff |first=Dave |url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/07/07/watching-the-jackson-memorial/?hp |title=Live Blogging the Jackson Memorial - ArtsBeat Blog - NYTimes.com |publisher=Artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com |date=July 7, 2009 |accessdate=July 21, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Geoff|last=Boucher|first2=Cara Mia|last2=DiMassa|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-michael-jackson-memorial8-2009jul08,0,4224405,print.story|title= Michael Jackson hailed during emotional memorial service|work=Los Angeles Times|date=July 7, 2009|accessdate=September 3, 2009|publisher=latimes.com}}</ref> Before broadcast of the service ended, a final slideshow of photos starting with Jackson's childhood and concluding with his final years played with Mariah Carey's version of "I'll Be There" playing.
===Guest list=== The participants were Ron Boyd (family friend), [[Los Angeles Lakers]] greats [[Magic Johnson]] and [[Kobe Bryant]], fellow [[Motown Records]] alumni [[Berry Gordy]], [[Lionel Richie]], [[Smokey Robinson]], and [[Stevie Wonder]], [[Mariah Carey]], [[Andrae Crouch]] (choir), [[Queen Latifah]], [[Judith Hill]] (recruited 'This Is It' performer), [[Jennifer Hudson]], [[Shaheen Jafargholi]] (a child finalist on ''[[Britain's Got Talent]]'', who sang a Jackson song), [[Martin Luther King III]], [[Bernice King|Bernice A. King]], [[John Mayer]], Omer Bhatti (a Norwegian rapper), [[Al Sharpton|Rev. Al Sharpton]], [[Brooke Shields]], Pastor Lucious Smith (family friend), and [[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]]. In, addition to the above persons, [[ABC News]] reported, [[Lionel Richie]]'s daughter [[Nicole Richie|Nicole]], who was Michael's goddaughter, and singers [[Akon]] and [[Sean "Diddy" Combs|Sean Combs]] would attend the services.<ref name=ABCAlist/>
Debbie Rowe, Jackson's ex-wife and mother of two of his three children, hoping not to be a distraction,<ref>{{cite video|title=[[Larry King Live]]|medium=television|date=July 6, 2009|publisher=CNN}}</ref> did not attend the funeral.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/print?id=8009534|title=Michael Jackson to be Buried in Famed Hollywood Cemetery|work=ABC News|date=July 6, 2009|publisher=ABCNEWS.com|first=Sarah|last=Netter|first2=Emily|last2=Friedman|accessdate=September 3, 2009}}</ref> [[Elizabeth Taylor]] and [[Diana Ross]], two of Jackson's closest friends, as well as Eliza Jackson Duphrey, Quincy Jones, Ivonne Ester Duphrey (Michael Jackson's cousins) also did not attend.<ref name=ABCAlist >{{cite news|first=Luchina|last=Fisher|first2=Sheila|last2=Marikar|url=http://www.abcnews.go.com/print?id=8015494|title=Michael Jackson's Memorial Lures A-List Attendees, Participants|work=ABC News|publisher=ABCNEWS.com|date=July 7, 2009}}</ref>
===Casket=== Jackson was presented in a gold-plated solid bronze Promethean casket furnished by the [[Batesville Casket Company]], which cost roughly $25,000. It is similar to the one in which [[James Brown]] was buried.<ref name=HarlowJuly5>{{cite news|first=John|last=Harlow|title=Police target 30 in hunt for Michael Jackson’s drug suppliers|work=The Sunday Times|date=July 5, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.casketsite.com/batesville/items/bronze/prometheanbronze.htm|title=Promethean Bronze|work=Caskets by Batesville}}</ref> The closed casket at the Staples Center was decorated with red roses and [[Bells of Ireland]] flower arrangement. The casket was escorted by Jackson's brothers, each wearing a single sequined white glove on the hand in which they held the casket. Jackson was originally to be buried on what would have been his 51st birthday, however the services were postponed and he was interred at [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park, Glendale|Forest Lawn Cemetery]] in Glendale on September 3, 2009.
===Live broadcast=== The service was broadcast live around the world, from the U.S. to Slovakia to parts of Asia. Public screenings were held in 37 cinemas across the U.S., as well as in Barcelona, Berlin, Brussels, Bucharest, Gothenburg, Lisbon, London, Madrid, Malmö, Oslo, Paris, Milan, Seville, Stockholm, and Tallinn.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://investor.cinedigm.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=394461|title=Broadcast of Jackson Memorial Service to Mann Chinese Six Theatre in Los Angeles, CA to Be Cancelled at Request of Los Angeles Police Department|work=Cinedigm Digital Cinema Corp.|date=July 7, 2009|publisher=cinedigm.com}}</ref> There was also a live broadcast at 3am in Melbourne, Australia at Federation Square.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jackson's world fans mourn idol before memorial|date=July 7, 2009|first=Jill|last=Lawless|agency=Associated Press}}</ref> Before the event, the organizers expected an estimated one billion viewers.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/07/08/AR2009070803095.html | work=The Washington Post | first=Lisa | last=de Moraes | title=Lisa De Moraes Column on Michael Jackson's Memorial Service | date=July 9, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://vancouversun.com/Entertainment/Michael+Jackson+billion+people+estimated+watching+gold+plated+casket+memorial+service/1767503/story.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-07-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090710103145/http://www.vancouversun.com/Entertainment/Michael+Jackson+billion+people+estimated+watching+gold+plated+casket+memorial+service/1767503/story.html |archivedate=July 10, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>[http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/32375160/ns/today-entertainment/]</ref> According to [[Nielsen ratings|Nielsen]], 31.1 million Americans watched the service live on television;<ref name="demoraes-ratings">{{cite news|url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/07/08/AR2009070803095.html/|title= Jackson's Memorial a Hit With Viewers but Not Quite Off the Charts|last=de Moraes|first=Lisa|date=July 9, 2009|publisher=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=July 14, 2009}}</ref> an amount comparable to the 35.1 million that watched the [[Death and state funeral of Ronald Reagan|state funeral of Ronald Reagan]] in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://television.aol.com/insidetv/2009/07/09/michael-jackson-memorial-earns-31-million-viewers/ |title=Michael Jackson Memorial Earns 31 Million Viewers & More TV News - Inside TV Blog |publisher=Television.aol.com |date=July 9, 2009 |accessdate=July 28, 2009}}</ref> According to some news sources the event exceeded 2.5 billion viewers, which would make it the most watched live television broadcast in history worldwide.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.in.msn.com/national/article.aspx?cp-documentid=5592621 |work=MSN |title=Hazarika''s funeral creates world record |date=July 8, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140807110046/http://news.in.msn.com/national/article.aspx?cp-documentid=5592621 |archivedate=August 7, 2014 }}</ref> Although this number is not widely agreed upon.
[[Image:MichaelJacksonMemorial 03.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department]] motorcycle detail patrolling the perimeter of the Staples Center during the memorial service.]]
Also in comparison to other big non-funeral related events, the [[first inauguration of Barack Obama]] in 2009 garnered about 38 million viewers, and the [[2008 Summer Olympics opening ceremony|opening ceremony of the 2008 Summer Olympics]] garnered about 34.2 million viewers in the U.S. alone.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/31804997/ns/entertainment-music/|date=July 13, 2009|accessdate=September 3, 2009|agency=Associated Press|title=31.1 million watched Jackson memorial|publisher=MSNBC.com}}</ref> The memorial service was the most watched event in online streaming history.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/TECH/07/07/michael.jackson.web.traffic/ |title=Michael Jackson memorial draws crowds online - CNN.com |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date= July 8, 2009|accessdate=July 28, 2009}}</ref> CNN's webcast drew at least 9.7 million streams; their feed on Ustream, 4.6 million streams; and MSNBC's feed via Justin.tv drew three million.<ref name="mashable-ratings">{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2009/07/07/cnn-live-stream-michael-jackson/|title=CNN Live Stream of Michael Jackson Memorial: 9.7 Million Views|last=Ostrow|first=Adam|date=July 7, 2009|publisher=Mashable|accessdate=July 8, 2009}}</ref>
===Media coverage === According to [[Global Language Monitor]], the coverage from the death and aftermath to the funeral of Michael Jackson tops [[Pope John Paul II]] as No.1 media (noting the longer timeframe and contentious circumstances re. the former).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.languagemonitor.com/about/news/michael-jackson-funeral-tops-pope-john-paul-ii-as-no-1-media/|title=Michael Jackson funeral tops Pope John Paul II as No. 1 media|publisher=Global Language Monitor}}</ref>
===Cost=== Due to the [[Great Recession in the United States|economic downturn]] concerns at the time, the city of Los Angeles said the memorial had cost the city $1.4 million for 1,400 police officers, trash pick-up, sanitation, and traffic control. The city set up a webpage asking fans for donations to help with the expenses, though it kept crashing. City Attorney Carmen Trutanich said it would be wrong to expect taxpayers to finance a private event. "The city attorney does not want something like this happening again, the city paying for a private event," spokesman John Franklin told CNN. "That's especially in a cash-strapped city, where people have been [[furlough]]ed or even lost jobs."<ref>{{cite news|last=Duke|first=Alan|first2=Ahmed|last2=Saeed|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/Music/07/09/jackson.wrap/index.html|title=More associates link Jackson to prescription drugs|work=CNN|date=July 8, 2009|publisher=CNN.com}}</ref>
